awd_titl_txt: The STEM Ambassador Program: Supporting Scientists' Engagement with Public Audiences
awd_abstract_narration:
As part of its overall strategy to enhance learning in informal environments, the Advancing Informal STEM Learning (AISL) program funds innovative research, approaches, and resources for use in a variety of settings.  Fostering greater inclusion in science creates benefits for both science and society.  In this Innovations and Development project, the University of Utah will investigate how to sustain and scale the STEM Ambassador Program (STEMAP), begun in 2016 with AISL funding.  STEMAP developed an innovative process to train scientists to engage members of the public, who cannot or do not gain access to science via conventional science education venues (such as museums, schools, zoos), by implementing activities in non-traditional settings. The 65 scientists trained by the initial STEMAP effort effectively engaged in over 45 settings including an affordable housing development, a youth residential treatment center, a state prison, a cooking class, a daycare facility, and several senior centers. The number of scientists applying to the program quickly exceeded STEMAP's capacity.  Other institutions expressed interest in replicating the training.  This project will explore strategies for scaling and sustaining public engagement training to support more scientists who can engage more people in more venues.  Outcomes will serve to inform the broader implementation of STEMAP and the efforts of other public engagement programs, many of which face similar scaling and sustainability challenges. 

Scaling and sustaining public engagement of science (PES) programs is a central challenge for many in the informal science learning community. This project will explore strategies to scale and sustain the STEM Ambassador Program.  Research questions include: (1) How do different program formats increase or restrict program capacity and engagement outcomes? (2) What benefits accrue to scientists and their institutions by participating in public engagement in science activities that might serve as motivators to continue these activities? (3) Are funding and organizational models developed in business and other professional settings applicable to sustaining these programs? To address scalability, this project will explore the effectiveness of three dissemination formats: (1) the creation of a mentorship program for in-person trainees, (2) a train-the-trainer approach, and (3) online training with in-person mentorship. The project team will create an evaluation toolkit with participant surveys, rubrics for observers, and "on-the-spot" assessment tools developed under AISL Award 1811022 to assess the effectiveness of engagement activities delivered by trainees in each of the three formats. To address sustainability, the project team will document the values of public engagement training to both the participating scientists and their institutions via surveys and interviews.  Consultants from the business sectors will create a PES Campus Council to explore possible financial, organizational, and leadership plans that will help sustain engagement efforts.  Outcomes will be published in peer-reviewed journals and compiled into a dissemination framework to inform actions to scale and sustain STEMAP and other public engagement of science programs to engage more hard-to-reach audiences. Inverness Research will serve as the project's external evaluator.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
We carried out design and development research on how to scale and sustain the STEM Ambassador Program (STEMAP), an innovative public engagement with science (PES) training model we previously created (DRL AISL 15-14494). The original program trained scientists at a single institution, the University of Utah (UU), to widen the reach of PES efforts to include ?hard-to-reach? groups who do not or cannot access science in traditional informal science education institutions.  

Scaling and sustaining PES training programs is a central challenge for the informal science education (ISE) and science communication communities; the expansion of successful programs is an effective and efficient way to increase the impact of PES training programs on scientists and their communities. We conducted formal studies on how to make our program accessible to scientists at other institutions and to sustain it at the UU. 

STEMAP training was developed at the UU and is based on three existing education and design models, presented as a semester-long (~four months) training consisting of five modules. We explored ways to scale the STEMAP program by innovating novel training formats with accompanying organizational and funding structures. We explored different combinations of trainers (UU STEMAP staff and faculty/ broader impacts staff at the other institutions) and various combinations of remote versus in-person approaches to delivery. Due to travel restrictions imposed by the COVID-19 pandemic, we delivered ?train-the-trainer? Site Leader trainings remotely, rather than in person.

Through these efforts, we were successful in scaling up the program. We offered STEMAP training to 252 Ambassadors across 13 cohorts at 14 institutions with our different models. The Site Leader Model proved highly effective and continues to operate at one of our partner universities with limited input from UU STEMAP staff. We provided our training to faculty, postdocs, graduate students, undergraduate students, and research staff representing over 40 STEM disciplines and departments outside of traditional STEM fields. 

We enhanced STEMAP sustainability by: 1) documenting the motivations and perceived values of STEMAP to participating scientists and relating those values to the values of academic institutions; 2) collaborating with social impact business consultants and academic administrators to explore financial models for program sustainability; 3) developing organizational and leadership structures; and 4) incentivizing participation through the development of micro-credentials.

Through these efforts, we successfully established a collaboration with the UU?s Office of the Vice President for Research (VPR) and the Interdisciplinary Exchange for Utah Science (NEXUS) to financially sustain STEMAP?s work through two memoranda of agreement. With support from the VPR office, we offered eight introductory broader impacts workshops for UU faculty and students and provided individual broader impacts consultations to scientists interested in developing innovative PES events outside the semester-long STEMAP program.

For our intellectual merit, the research and evaluation team conducted surveys and interviews with participating scientists and analyzed these with qualitative and quantitative approaches. Community group feedback was collected via surveys where possible. In external evaluation surveys, Ambassadors reported benefits from their participation in the training consistent with the overall goals of STEMAP, particularly regarding making connections and building relationships with focal groups, interest in continuing to engage in public engagement with new audiences, and contributions to their skills in engaging with the public around science. Key results from our research team?s quantitative surveys and qualitative interviews revealed that scientists found great value in STEMAP and its focus on relationship building, including increased confidence in conducting outreach. However, there were some challenges, including the lack of institutional support for public science engagement efforts and the time-intensive nature of the STEMAP public engagement model. The results of this research will be published in a peer-reviewed science communication journal and posted on the STEMAP website. 

Our broader impacts include insights and peer-reviewed publications about how to scale and sustain a PES program like STEMAP. This will result in more scientists effectively engaging more people in non-traditional venues. Our STEM Ambassadors received professional development training and engaged public audiences in over 100 unique community venues. We have built a community of trainers, mentors, and Ambassadors that can sustain these efforts in the aggregate. A major part of this project was to engage community audiences in ways that could broaden the participation of underrepresented scientists and public audiences. 

STEMAP engagement outcomes were disseminated to public and academic audiences via the STEMAP website (www.stemap.org), newsletter, social media accounts (@stemapteam), five peer-reviewed publications, and dozens of presentations at regional and national conferences and meetings. Finalized training materials were compiled into an implementation manual to guide others in carrying out STEMAP training at their own institutions. Our seven-member Advisory Board provided valuable guidance throughout. The STEMAP program also provided valuable professional development opportunities for three UU staff members and three interns. This project has met all six of AISL's priority areas.
